content: The "Nuclear Captain Prevention Act of 2006" may be cited as the short title. Definitions are provided in Section 2. The Act defines key terms such as "Convention on the Physical Protection of Nuclear Material," "design-basis threat," "formula quantities of strategic special nuclear material," and "Nuclear Non-Proliferation Treaty." The Act defines terms like "strategic special nuclear material," "Nuclear Non-Proliferation Treaty," and "nuclear weapon." SEC. 3. FINDINGS. Congress finds that the threat of terrorists acquiring and using a nuclear weapon is urgent and poses a significant risk to national and global security. Efforts to secure nuclear stockpiles and prevent nuclear smuggling have made progress, but more actions are necessary to reduce the threat of nuclear terrorism. The White House's National Strategy for Combating Terrorism highlights the grave danger of weapons of mass destruction in the hands of terrorists. UN Secretary-General Kofi Annan warns that a nuclear terror attack would have devastating consequences on a global scale. UN Security Council Resolution 1540 emphasizes the importance of combating this threat through all available means. United Nations Security Council Resolution 1540 (2004) emphasizes the need for all countries to adopt and enforce laws prohibiting non-state actors from acquiring and using nuclear, chemical, or biological weapons for terrorist purposes. The Director General of the International Atomic Energy Agency warns of the urgent need to prevent a terrorist attack using a nuclear weapon. The Director General of the International Atomic Energy Agency, Dr. Mohammed El Baradei, warns of the urgent need to prevent a terrorist attack using a nuclear weapon, describing it as a "race against time." Sense of Congress on the prevention of nuclear terrorism. The sense of Congress is that the threat of nuclear terror is the most horrific the US faces. A comprehensive approach is needed to reduce this danger, including efforts to eliminate terrorist groups seeking nuclear weapons, secure nuclear weapons globally, and prevent terrorist manufacturing or transportation of nuclear explosives. The prevention of a nuclear terrorist attack on the US should be a top priority for the President. Within a comprehensive strategy to prevent nuclear terrorism, it is crucial to secure all nuclear weapons and special nuclear material worldwide. The President should prioritize preventing a nuclear terrorist attack on the United States and accelerate programs to combat nuclear smuggling. The International Atomic Energy Agency plays a vital role in coordinating international efforts to protect nuclear materials. Legislation by Senators Lugar, Domenici, and Nunn has led to groundbreaking programs to prevent nuclear weapons from falling into the hands of terrorists. The National Security Act of 1947 is amended to include a new section for a senior advisor to the president for the prevention of nuclear terrorism. The National Security Act of 1947 is amended to include a Senior Advisor to the President for the Prevention of Nuclear Terrorism, appointed by the President with Senate approval. The Senior Advisor advises on nuclear terrorism matters, formulates prevention policies, develops plans with measurable targets, addresses program gaps, and oversees program implementation strategies. The Senior Advisor to the President for the Prevention of Nuclear Terrorism oversees the development of program implementation strategies, budget requests, and new initiatives to prevent nuclear terrorism. They also coordinate US efforts to implement policies and may appoint necessary personnel. The Senior Advisor to the President for the Prevention of Nuclear Terrorism is added as a member of the National Security Council. The Senior Advisor to the President for the Prevention of Nuclear Terrorism is added as a member of the National Security Council. Additionally, an annual report is required. The President must submit an annual report to Congress on the security of strategic special nuclear material, including a survey of facilities worldwide and a list of high-priority sites. The annual report to Congress includes a list of facilities worldwide containing nuclear weapons or special nuclear material, prioritized for security measures. It also outlines a plan for securing or removing these materials, with measurable milestones and estimated costs. The annual report to Congress includes a plan for securing weapons, strategic special nuclear material, and related equipment at vulnerable facilities worldwide, with measurable milestones and estimated costs. The report also covers efforts to establish security standards and policies, which may be submitted in classified form but must include a detailed unclassified summary. SEC. 7 outlines the minimum security standard for nuclear weapons and strategic special nuclear materials. The United States aims to rapidly secure all nuclear weapons and special nuclear materials. In line with international standards, the President will work towards a global nuclear security standard that effectively protects against threats from terrorists and criminals, considering equipment and human limitations, and is verifiable. The President will work with other countries and the International Atomic Energy Agency to upgrade nuclear security globally, ensuring that all countries with nuclear weapons or special nuclear materials meet the required standard promptly and sustainably. United States will provide financial and technical assistance for this purpose. The President will work with other countries and the International Atomic Energy Agency to ensure effective nuclear security rules and regulations are in place worldwide, including the implementation of a regulatory design-basis threat model to defeat threats from terrorists and criminals. Authorization of appropriations for fiscal year 2008: $50,000,000 to increase international participation in converting nuclear facilities from highly enriched uranium to low enriched uranium and to remove highly enriched uranium from such facilities.
